hedline.hl1: Bedford Budget Opponents Cite Financial Mishandling

abstract.p: Philip Christe letter holds June 18 article on fight over school budget in Bedford, NY, contained unfounded allegations of bigotry; editor's note: budget has been approved (S)

block.p: Two basic standards in journalism were ignored in the story on the Bedford schools' budget battles.
Unfounded allegations of bigotry were published without a source or evidence. Secondly, no one, myself included, who opposed the $65.7 million budget was contacted.
Two basic standards in journalism were ignored in the story on the Bedford schools' budget battles.
Unfounded allegations of bigotry were published without a source or evidence. Secondly, no one, myself included, who opposed the $65.7 million budget was contacted.
Being very much in the middle of all this, I can assure readers that anti-Hispanic bigotry and ''class division'' never entered the picture.

Is it possible to understand that reasonable people can object to a $65.7 million dollar budget that involves $4.9 million in new, additional property taxes? We are already at least 25 percent higher in our per-pupil costs than similar districts and 45 percent higher than the New York State average.

Financial mismanagement and shortsighted planning is par for the course in Bedford Central. For the last two years it has overspent its approved budgets by 2 percent or $1 million. Last summer, $1.5 million in UNUM Health Insurance Company stock appeared out of nowhere in the business office; $750,000 in alleged savings in health insurance turned into a $750,000 deficit.

Regarding teacher salaries, I purchased a full-page advertisement in Bedford's Record-Review listing three years of W-2 wages for the top 300 district employees. Everyone understands a W-2. It tells the real compensation story.
Editor's note: The basic Bedford school budget passed by a vote of 2,742 to 2,093 last Tuesday.
